item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the portion of the resolution electing the CAO Agreed to by voice vote. (consideration: CR H1233; text as passed House: CR H1230)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the portion of the resolution electing the CAO Agreed to by voice vote.(consideration: CR H1233; text as passed House: CR H1230)
On agreeing to the portion of the resolution electing the Clerk Agreed to by voice vote. (consideration: CR H1233; text as passed House: CR H1230)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the portion of the resolution electing the Clerk Agreed to by voice vote.(consideration: CR H1233; text as passed House: CR H1230)

DIVISION OF THE QUESTION - Mr. Ehlers demanded that the question of adoption be divided. Without objection, the question was divided and the Chair put the question on adoption of each portion of the resolution. (consideration: CR H1233)
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 129.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR H1230-1233)

summary.text: Elects the following officers of the House of Representatives: (1) Lorraine C. Miller as the Clerk; and (2) Daniel P. Beard as Chief Administrative Officer.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

Elects the following officers of the House of Representatives: (1) Lorraine C. Miller as the Clerk; and (2) Daniel P. Beard as Chief Administrative Officer.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
